Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Causes, Consequences, and Contestation in Pro Bono Lawyering

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The principle and practice of pro bono -- volunteer legal services for poor and other marginalized groups -- is an increasingly important feature of civil legal aid systems. A quarter century ago, pro bono was an ancillary feature of legal services. Now, in contrast, it has become widely diffused and institutionally central in a growing number of justice systems. Yet as pro bono spreads, promoted by powerful sponsors and mobilized by local lawyers, law firms, and the organized bar, it develops in diverse ways that reveal different approaches and unique understandings of the role that volunteer services should play in system design. What does the rise of pro bono mean for the pursuit of access to justice?

Empirical research is essential to better understanding how pro bono operates in different contexts. Toward that end, this travel grant will bring together leading and emerging law and social science scholars to explore how pro bono has been shaped by cross-cutting factors: the relative independence of the local legal profession, the structure of government, the development of large law firms and the power of corporate clients, potential competition with the plaintiffs' bar, the interaction between market-based and state-based systems for providing legal services to the poor, the influence of major private funders, the role of legal education, and the local nature of the legal need.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our major goal was to convene a workshop to forge connections among law and social science researchers undertaking studies of pro bono and its relation to access to justice around the globe. We aimed to invite participants from the six major continents to contribute perspectives from diverse regions and countries that have experienced important changes in their pro bono systems. We conceived of this workshop as part of a broader network building project that had been initiated with a Harvard Law School conference on global pro bono in the Spring of 2014 and deepened with a meeting at the 2017 International Meeting of the Law and Society Association in Mexico City in the Summer of 2017. We aimed to extend the conversation with a 2017 meeting at the UCLA School of Law on Global Pro Bono, at which participants would distribute and share drafts of country-specific studies of pro bono?s development in approximately 20 key countries.

We envisioned the workshop as one that would spur much-needed interdisciplinary and comparative dialogue on pro bono as a linchpin of access to justice. Toward that end, our goal was to convene four sessions organized around geographic regions (Americas, Africa, Asia and Europe) with another small-group session to discuss cross-cutting themes and comparative analysis. For each session, we planned to have discussants to offer analysis on the papers and presentations; the small-group discussion at the end was designed to think through connections raised throughout the day and to plan ongoing frameworks for participation and exchange.

On November 10, we held a successful Global Pro Bono Workshop at the UCLA School of Law in Los Angeles, California. The day was organized around four key panels that focused on pro bono's development in different regions around the world. We had a total of 17 participants presenting research on 13 countries. In addition to the organizers, these were: Daniel Bonilla, University of Los Andes, Colombia; Steve Boutcher, University of Massachusetts, Amherst & John Bliss, Center for the Legal Profession, Harvard Law School; Arpita Gupta, University of Wisconsin; Jin Dong, GTA Education, China; Helena Whalen-Bridge, National University of Singapore; Thabang Pooe, Gender Justice; Jayanth Krishnan, Indiana University Maurer School of Law; Edwin Rekosh, Cardozo Law School & Lamin Khadar, DLA Piper, Amsterdam; Jeremy Perelman, Science Po Law; Leire Laracocechea San Sebastian, Vance Center for International Justice; and Susana Santos, ISCTE-IUL University Institute of Lisbon.

The conference yielded important exchanges that have laid the foundation for significant results. Thirteen papers or presentations were circulated and the focus of the workshop was on sharing preliminary results and standardizing questions, methodology, and findings in order to facilitate comparative analysis. The panels were highly successful venues for critical dialogue in which the participants were asked to frame their analysis around the conference themes of causes, consequences, and contestation. There was robust contestation over the meaning of pro bono in the different countries represented in our project and over the metrics we should be using to evaluate pro bono's development and success. Based on these discussions, we were able to sharpen our analytical framework and themes by disaggregating countries based on distinctive forces shaping pro bono's institutionalization.

This project is the first of its kind to explore the growing role of pro bono in legal professions around the world. Although public service is often considered intrinsic to the profession, our project investigates why professions in different parts of the world have recently developed more specific ideas and practices in support of private lawyers providing free legal services to poor and underrepresented groups. Our approach is to explore this question comparatively and transnationally, contributing to the burgeoning literature in law and sociology on comparative professional analysis. The contributors to this project are leading experts in pro bono from across the globe, whose chapters span an impressive range of countries, exploring both the internal roots of and global influences on pro bono in national context. These country studies reflect the increasing geographical reach of pro bono and also underscore its complex meaning in different parts of the world.

The results from the conference will be published in our forthcoming book, Global Pro Bono: Causes, Consequences, and Contestation, which is under contract to be published by Cambridge University Press with a target date of Fall 2019. We have also been contacted by the Law & Society series editors at CUP and have accepted their offer to have our volume appear under that series.
